 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td width="3%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:3.86%;">
  <p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(5)</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="96%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:96.14%;">
  <p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Shares
  earned and accrued under the IBM Deferred Compensation and Equity Award Plan
  (DCEAP) as of December&nbsp;31, 2008, including dividend equivalents credited
  with respect to such shares. Upon a director&#146;s retirement, these shares are
  payable in cash or stock at the director&#146;s choice (see 2008 Director
  Compensation Narrative for additional information).</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td width="3%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:3.86%;">
  <p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="96%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:96.14%;">
  <p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td width="3%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:3.86%;">
  <p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(6)</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="96%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:96.14%;">
  <p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Includes
  324 shares in which voting and investment power are shared.</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td width="3%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:3.86%;">

  and investment power are shared.</font></p>

  </td>

  <p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
  total of these three columns represents less than 1% of the outstanding
  shares, and no individual&#146;s beneficial holdings totaled more than 1/5 of 1%
  of the outstanding shares.</font></p>
  </td>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">15</font></p>

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='15',FILE='C:\JMS\tdurenb\09-1945-1\task3394958\1945-1-bc-03.htm',USER='tdurenb',CD='Feb 27 16:47 2009' -->



<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Executive Compensation</font></b><a name="ExecutiveCompensation_061447"></a></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">2008
REPORT OF THE EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION AND MANAGEMENT RESOURCES COMMITTEE</font>  </font>OF THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS<a name="a2008ReportOfTheExecutiveCompensa_061533"></a></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Set
out below is the Compensation Discussion and Analysis, which is a discussion of
the Company&#146;s executive compensation programs and policies written from the
perspective of how we and management view and use such programs and policies.
Given the Committee&#146;s role in providing oversight to the design of those
programs and policies, and in making specific compensation decisions for senior
executives using those policies and programs, the Committee participated in the
preparation of the Compensation Discussion and Analysis, reviewing successive
drafts of the document and discussing those with management. The Committee
recommended to the Board that the Compensation Discussion and Analysis be
included in this proxy Statement. We join with management in welcoming readers
to examine our pay practices and in affirming the commitment of these pay
practices to the longterm interests of stockholders.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Sidney
Taurel (chair)</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Alain
J.P. Belda</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">William
R. Brody</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">2008 Compensation Discussion and Analysis</font></b><a name="a2008CompensationDiscussionAndAna_061632"></a></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">PREAMBLE:
RECENT EVENTS</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
recent unprecedented events related to the collapse of the financial markets in
2008 has prompted investors to question the role that executive compensation
programs may have had in contributing to excessive risk taking by senior
executives to achieve short-term financial gain at the expense of the long-term
health of a company. In light of this, we again reviewed the objectives and
design of IBM&#146;s executive compensation program and its related plans and
policies so that we could assure our investors that our approach encourages the
right decisions and behaviors to align with the long-term interests of our
stockholders. We concluded the following:</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:8.5pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Our
programs appropriately balance short- and long-term incentives, with
approximately 60% of total target compensation for the senior executive team
provided in equity and focused on long-term performance.</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:8.5pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Our
executive compensation program pays for performance against financial targets
that are set to be challenging to motivate a high degree of business
performance, with an emphasis on longer-term financial success and prudent risk
management.</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:8.5pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Qualitative
factors beyond the quantitative financial metrics are a key consideration in
the determination of individual executive compensation payments. How our
executives achieve their financial results, integrate across lines of business,
and demonstrate leadership consistent with the IBM values are key to individual
compensation decisions.</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:8.5pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>As
explained in the &#147;2008 Potential Payments upon Termination Narrative,&#148; we
further strengthened our retirement policies on equity grants for our senior
leaders beginning in 2009 to ensure that the long-term interests of the Company
continue to be the focus even as these executives approach retirement.</p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">16</font></p>

<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='16',FILE='C:\JMS\kdefran\09-1945-1\task3394969\1945-1-bc-05.htm',USER='kdefran',CD='Feb 27 16:48 2009' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:8.5pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Our share
ownership guidelines require that our senior executives hold a significant
amount of IBM equity to further align their interests with stockholders over
the long term.</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:8.5pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>IBM has a
policy for &#147;clawback&#148; of cash incentive payments in the event that an officer&#146;s
conduct leads to a restatement of the Company&#146;s financial results. Likewise,
the Company&#146;s equity plan has a &#147;clawback&#148; provision which states that awards
will be cancelled and certain gains must be repaid if an executive engages in
detrimental activity.</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
remainder of this Compensation Discussion and Analysis describes the key
features of our executive compensation program in detail. We are confident that
our program is aligned to the interests of our stockholders, rewards for
performance, and is an example of the strong pay practice emphasized by expert
commentators on this topic.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">SECTION
1: EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION SUMMARY &#151; WHY WE PAY WHAT WE DO<a name="Section1ExecutiveCompensationSumm_061623"></a></font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Trust
and personal responsibility in <i>all</i>
relationships &#151; relationships with clients, partners, communities, fellow
IBMers, and investors &#151; is a core value at IBM. Investors should have as much
trust in the integrity of a company&#146;s executive compensation process as clients
do in the quality of its products. A breach of this trust is unacceptable. As a
part of maintaining this trust, we well understand the need for our investors &#151;
not only professional fund managers and institutional investor groups, but also
millions of individual investors &#151; to know how compensation decisions are made.
We have put tremendous effort and rigor into our own executive compensation
processes over many years, continually updating them to meet new voluntary
criteria as well as official requirements from the SEC.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">Investors
&#151; IBM&#146;s owners &#151; want senior leaders to run the Company in a way that protects
and grows their investment over the long term while appropriately managing
risk. This is no simple task at any company, and at a company as large and
complex as IBM, it is a particularly exciting leadership challenge. IBM holds a
unique identity, based on talent, brand, global operating footprint, the size
and scope of our business overall, and the size of each of our individual lines
of business. Unlike those few other companies of comparable size and scale that
tend to operate as holding companies of component businesses, we operate as an
integrated entity across a number</font>  </font>of significant business lines, most large enough to be among the Fortune
150 biggest companies if they were stand-alone businesses. Our unique,
integrated model delivers great value to our investors and our clients, and
demands a senior leadership team of unusual depth, agility and experience.</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">To
that end, IBM&#146;s executive compensation practices are designed specifically to
meet five key objectives:</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.15in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:8.5pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Ensure
that the interests of IBM&#146;s leaders are closely aligned with those of our
investors and owners;</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:8.5pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Attract
and retain highly qualified senior leaders who can drive a global enterprise to
succeed in today&#146;s competitive marketplace;</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:8.5pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Motivate
our leaders to deliver a high degree of business performance without
encouraging unnecessary and excessive risk taking;</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:8.5pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Differentiate
compensation so that it varies based on individual and team performance; and</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:8.5pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Balance
rewards for both short-term results and the longterm strategic decisions needed
to ensure sustained business performance over time.</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">With
these goals in mind, IBM executives earn their compensation based on
performance over three time frames:</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<div align="center">

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" style="border-collapse:collapse;width:100.06%;">
 <tr>
  <td width="9%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:9.0%;">
  <p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="14%" valign="top" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:14.4%;">
  <p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Current Year&#146;s</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="8%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:8.62%;">
  <p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:2.02%;">

  </td>

  <p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Full Career</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="9%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:9.02%;">
  <p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td width="9%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:9.0%;">

  </td>
  <td width="14%" valign="top" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:14.4%;">
  <p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Performance:</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="8%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:8.62%;">
  <p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

  </td>
  <td width="9%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:9.3%;">

  <p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Performance:</font></b></p>

  <td width="8%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:8.28%;">

  </td>
  <td width="8%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:8.54%;">
  <p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="14%" valign="top" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:14.4%;">
  <p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Performance:</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="9%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:9.02%;">

  <td width="9%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:9.0%;">

  </td>
  <td width="14%" valign="top" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:14.4%;">
  <p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Salary and Annual</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="8%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:8.62%;">

  </td>

  <p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Long-term</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="8%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:8.28%;">
  <p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:2.0%;">
  <p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>

  </td>
  <td width="14%" valign="top" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:14.4%;">
  <p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Retention, Pension</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="9%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:9.02%;">
  <p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td width="9%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:9.0%;">

  </td>
  <td width="14%" valign="top" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:14.4%;">
  <p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Incentives</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="8%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:8.62%;">
  <p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:2.02%;">
  <p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;font-weight:bold;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="9%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:9.3%;">

  </td>
  <td width="14%" valign="top" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:14.4%;">
  <p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Incentive Plan</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="8%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:8.28%;">
  <p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:2.0%;">
  <p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;font-weight:bold;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="8%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:8.54%;">
  <p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="14%" valign="top" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:14.4%;">
  <p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;font-weight:bold;">and Savings</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="9%" valign="top" style="padding:0in .7pt 0in .7pt;width:9.02%;">
  <p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

</div>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">1.</font><font size="1" style="font-size:8.5pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Current &#151; Salary and annual incentives that
reflect actions and results over 12 months;</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .15in;text-indent:-.15in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">2.</font><font size="1" style="font-size:8.5pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Longer-term &#151; A long-term incentive plan that
reflects results over a minimum of three years, helping to ensure that current
results remain sustainable; and</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .15in;text-indent:-.15in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">3.</font><font size="1" style="font-size:8.5pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Full Career &#151; Deferrals, retention payments
and retirement accumulations help ensure today&#146;s leaders stay with IBM until
their working careers end.</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .2in;text-indent:-.15in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">COMPENSATION
ELEMENTS FOR SENIOR LEADERS</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On
average, 87% of IBM&#146;s senior leaders&#146; annual compensation varies year to year
based on business results, with the remainder coming from salary. In addition,
60% of the Chairman and CEO&#146;s annual pay and 63% of the Senior Vice Presidents&#146;
(SVP) pay, on average, is in long term elements. This ensures that the
interests of senior executives are aligned with stockholders.</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">17</font></p>

<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='17',FILE='C:\JMS\kdefran\09-1945-1\task3394969\1945-1-bc-05.htm',USER='kdefran',CD='Feb 27 16:48 2009' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><img width="654" height="250" src="g19451bc05i001.jpg"></font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Current Year&#146;s Performance: Salary and Annual Incentives</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Salary</font></i>.
Senior leaders at IBM receive a small percentage of their overall compensation
in salary. In 2008, for example, Chairman and CEO Sam Palmisano earned 10% of
his compensation in salary, and the rest of the senior team earned an average
of 13% of their average compensation in salary.</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Annual Incentive</font></i>.
Senior leaders are incented through a program that sets performance targets
based on their role and scope. Actual payments are driven by business
performance against revenue growth, net income, and cash flow targets and
individual performance, as reflected in the Personal Business Commitment review
process described under &#147;How Compensation Decisions Are Made.&#148; Top performers
earn the greatest payouts; median performers earn much smaller amounts; and the
lowest performers earn no incentive payments at all. Over the past five years,
these results-based payouts for individual leaders have ranged from 0.7 times
target to a high of 1.66 times target. In 2008, the annual incentive earned by
the Chairman and CEO represented 30% of his total compensation; incentives
achieved by the rest of the senior team averaged 18% of their total
compensation. Additional information about the Annual Incentive Program is
outlined in Section&nbsp;2 of this CD&amp;A, &#147;Setting Performance Targets for
Incentive Compensation.&#148;</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Team Incentive.</font></i> When
Mr.&nbsp;Palmisano became CEO in 2002, he asked the Board of Directors to take
a portion of the annual incentive funding (approximately $3 million) to help
create a pool for rewarding teamwork by his most senior leaders. This was done
to reinforce IBM&#146;s strategy of integration across the Company, with awards
based on how well the SVPs lead efforts to deliver integrated value to IBM&#146;s
clients worldwide. For the past six years, an amount ranging up to $250,000 was
awarded and paid equally to each member of the senior team. The Chairman and
CEO was not eligible to receive a team incentive. In 2008, the SVP team earned
the maximum payout of $250,000 for the first time. This represented an average
of 6% of total compensation for the SVPs. Given the team&#146;s achievement and in
recognition that integration is now part of the management culture, the Team
Incentive was discontinued beginning in 2009.</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Other Compensation</font></i>.
Disclosure rules&nbsp;require that companies include certain items in the
Summary Compensation Table column entitled &#147;All Other Compensation.&#148; At IBM,
many of these items are available to all employees. In fact, additional
programs that are restricted to senior executive participation amount to less
than 1% of their total compensation on average. These programs are limited to
services with a direct bearing on individual productivity or security. IBM&#146;s
security practices provide that all air travel by the Chairman and CEO, including personal travel,
be on Company aircraft. IBM does not provide any tax assistance to Mr.&nbsp;Palmisano
in connection with taxes incurred for personal travel by him on the corporate</p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">18</font></p>

<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='18',FILE='C:\JMS\kdefran\09-1945-1\task3394969\1945-1-bc-05.htm',USER='kdefran',CD='Feb 27 16:48 2009' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">aircraft.
While the cost of corporate aircraft usage varies year to year based on several
external factors like fuel costs, using corporate aircraft for all travel is a
prudent step to ensure the safety of the Chairman and CEO given the breadth of
IBM&#146;s operations in over 170 countries which includes many emerging markets
where security threats are a reality. Given the personal travel security
practice for the Chairman and CEO, family members periodically accompany him on
the corporate aircraft. In accordance with tax requirements, income was imputed
to Mr.&nbsp;Palmisano for personal travel by his family members on the
corporate aircraft. In recognition of his family&#146;s personal travel, Mr.&nbsp;Palmisano
has contributed $80,000 to the IBM International Foundation to fund
contributions to the National Museum of African American History and Culture
for which he serves as a member of the advisory council.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Longer-Term Performance: Long-Term Incentive Plan</font></b> </p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Long-term
incentive plans (LTIP) have been a focal point for much of the discussion over
executive compensation in the past several years. Well-designed LTIPs ensure
that senior leaders hold a competitive stake in their company&#146;s financial
future. At the same time, the size of the awards reflects the value that the
company and, ultimately, its investors place on the individual executive at the
time. Any gain the executives realize in the long run from the program depends
on what they and their colleagues do to drive the financial performance of the
company. Under IBM&#146;s LTIP, senior leaders may receive certain grants of IBM
equity, as explained below.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Performance Share Unit (PSU) Grants</font></i>. This portion of the LTIP focuses senior
leaders on delivering business performance over the next three years against
two key financial metrics which drive long-term stockholder value &#151; earnings
per share and cash flow. Through this program, senior leaders are eligible to
earn a target number of shares of IBM stock at the end of a three-year
performance period. The award pays out at the end of the three years depending
on how well the Company performed against targets set at the beginning of the
three-year period. The payouts are made in shares of stock, so the value goes
up or down based on stock price performance from the beginning of the grant.
Additional information about PSUs is set forth in Section&nbsp;2 of this
CD&amp;A, &#147;Setting Performance Targets for Incentive Compensation.&#148;</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">Over
the past eight years, program payouts have ranged from a low of 54% to a high
of 147% of the target number of shares. In 2008, the long-term incentive grant
to the Chairman and CEO was comprised entirely of PSUs, representing 60% of his
total compensation assuming future performance</font>  </font>at target. PSUs were, on average, 44% of the
SVPs&#146; total compensation in 2008. In 2009, the annual long-term incentive grant
for SVPs will be entirely PSUs.</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
IBM Integration&nbsp;&amp; Values Team (I&amp;VT) consists of a select group of
approximately 300 executives charged with working beyond the scope of their
regular job responsibilities to drive growth through integration and
demonstrating IBM&#146;s values. The Chairman and CEO may grant members of this
group additional performance shares (Chairman&#146;s Performance Uplift) for
delivering extraordinary results. The Chairman and CEO and SVPs are not
eligible for these I&amp;VT awards.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.15in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Other Stock-Based Grants.</font></i> Another portion of the LTIP provides for
stock-based grants to focus senior leaders on delivering performance that
increases the value of the Company through growth of IBM&#146;s stock price over the
long term. Senior leaders may receive these grants in the form of stock
options, restricted stock, restricted stock units or any combination. The
grants vest &#151; become available for sale or exercise &#151; over time, typically over
either three or four years. Until vested, the grants have no value, except that
dividend equivalents are paid on restricted stock units granted prior to January&nbsp;1,
2008. For restricted stock units awarded after December&nbsp;31, 2007, dividend
equivalents are not paid. Executives awarded these grants typically hold them
for extended periods, and have up to 10 years to convert stock option awards to
cash or shares. The planned value of the annual other stock-based awards
granted in 2008 represented, on average, 19% of the total compensation for the
SVPs. As in 2008, the Board has not approved other stock-based grants for the
Chairman and CEO in 2009. Similarly, the Compensation Committee has not
approved other stock-based grants for the SVPs in 2009.</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">From
2005 through 2007, market-priced stock options were awarded to executives,
including some named executive officers, who chose to participate in an IBM
stock investment program. Under this program, which has since been
discontinued, executives could invest 5, 10 or 15% of their annual incentive
plan payout in IBM stock equivalents and receive IBM stock options, under the
terms of the IBM Long-Term Performance Plan, valued at two times their
investment.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.15in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
values of the other stock-based grants made in 2008 are shown in the Grants of Plan-Based
Awards Table. The 2008 expense associated with all outstanding awards,
including grants made in 2008 and prior years, is shown in the 2008 Summary
Compensation Table.</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">19</font></p>

<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='19',FILE='C:\JMS\kdefran\09-1945-1\task3394969\1945-1-bc-05.htm',USER='kdefran',CD='Feb 27 16:48 2009' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Full Career Performance:</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Retention, Pension and Savings</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Retention
of our key leaders for a full career is an important element of our total
compensation strategy. This is accomplished through a combination of retention
payments and retirement plans.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Retention Stock-Based Grants&nbsp;&amp; Cash Awards</font></i>. Periodically, Chairman and CEO Palmisano
reviews outstanding stock-based awards for the members of his senior leadership
team and other key executives. Depending on individual performance and the
competitive environment for senior executive leadership talent, he may
recommend that the Compensation Committee approve individual retention awards,
in the form of restricted stock units or cash, for certain executives. The
retention restricted stock unit (RRSU) grants typically vest at the end of five
years, and the cash awards have a clawback (i.e., repayment clause) if an
executive leaves IBM before a specified date. These awards make it more
difficult for other companies to recruit IBM&#146;s top talent.</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Closed Retention Plan</font></i>. In 1995, IBM created a new plan to help
retain, for their full careers, the caliber of senior leaders needed to turn
the Company around, preserve its long-term viability, and position it for
growth in the future. To discourage these leaders from joining competitors,
their benefits under this retention plan would be forfeited if they left IBM
prior to the end of a full career, typically age 60. The approach worked, as
evidenced by the Company&#146;s historic turnaround in the late 1990s, and its
current position of market leadership. Twelve of the Company&#146;s top 14
executives, including all of the named executive officers, were with IBM and
eligible for the Retention Plan when it was introduced and remain with the
Company today. Because its original purpose had been met, the plan was closed
to new participants in 2004. Future accruals under the plan stopped on December&nbsp;31,
2007, and the Retention Plan will not be replaced by any other plan.</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Pension</font></i>.
Prior to 2008, IBM&#146;s senior executives and other IBM employees in the U.S.
participated in pension plans. Future accruals under the pension plans stopped
on December&nbsp;31, 2007. The amount of the pension benefit under these plans
is based on pay and service and determined by the same formulas for executives
and non-executives.</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Savings</font></i>.
The money that U.S. executives save through the IBM 401(k)&nbsp;Plus Plan
(formerly the IBM Savings Plan), as for all U.S. employees, is eligible for a
Company match. Prior to January&nbsp;1, 2008, this match equaled 50% of the
first 6% of eligible pay that participants save through the plan for those
hired before January&nbsp;1, 2005, and 100% of the first 6% saved for those
hired after December&nbsp;31, 2004. As announced in early 2006, effective January&nbsp;1,
2008, the provisions of the Savings Plan were changed, and it was renamed the
401(k)&nbsp;Plus Plan, becoming the only tax-qualified retirement program
available to IBM&#146;s U.S. employees for future deferrals and employer
contributions. Under the new provisions of the plan, IBM matches a
participant&#146;s own contributions dollar-for-dollar up to 6% of eligible pay for
those hired before January&nbsp;1, 2005, and up to 5% for those hired on or
after that date. In addition, IBM makes automatic contributions to a
participant&#146;s 401(k)&nbsp;Plus account &#151; equal to 1%, 2% or 4% of a
participant&#146;s eligible pay &#151; depending on the participant&#146;s pension plan
eligibility on December&nbsp;31, 2007. Further, IBM contributes transition
credits to participants who were eligible to receive transition credits under
their Personal Pension Account. Transition credits are equal to 1%, 2%, 3% or
4% of a participant&#146;s eligible pay up to the Internal Revenue Code pay limit,
based on a participant&#146;s age and service as of June&nbsp;30, 1999. Transition
credits will stop on the earliest of the following dates: (i)&nbsp;June&nbsp;30,
2009, (ii)&nbsp;the date the participant reaches 30 years of service, or (iii)&nbsp;the
participant&#146;s termination of employment. Matching contributions and automatic
contributions are made once a participant has completed one year of service.</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In
the U.S., the Department of Labor and Internal Revenue Service also permit
individuals who exceed certain income thresholds to defer, on a nonqualified
basis, receipt of compensation they earn. This also allows IBM to delay paying
these obligations and, until they come due and are paid, IBM retains the cash
for operating purposes. In simple terms, this deferred compensation is money
earned in the past, but not yet paid out. Amounts deferred into the Excess 401(k)&nbsp;Plus
Plan are recordkeeping (notional) accounts and are not held in trust for the
participants. Participants in IBM&#146;s nonqualified plan, the Excess 401(k)&nbsp;Plus
Plan (formerly the Executive Deferred Compensation Plan) may invest their
notional accounts in the primary investment options available to all employees
through the 401(k)&nbsp;Plus Plan. Participants in the Excess 401(k)&nbsp;Plus
Plan are also eligible to receive company match, automatic contributions, and
transition credits, if applicable, on eligible pay deferred into the Excess 401(k)&nbsp;Plus</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">20</font></p>

<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='20',FILE='C:\JMS\kdefran\09-1945-1\task3394969\1945-1-bc-05.htm',USER='kdefran',CD='Feb 27 16:48 2009' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Plan
and on money earned in excess of the Internal Revenue Code pay limit once they
have completed one year of service. IBM does not pay guaranteed, above-market
or preferential earnings on deferred compensation. For executives with long and
successful careers at a single company, the deferrals can accumulate to
sizeable amounts over time.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
current value of Chairman and CEO Palmisano&#146;s account, made up of money he
earned during the past 13 years that the program has been available, is now worth
approximately $30 million. Before he was named Chairman and CEO in January&nbsp;2003,
Mr.&nbsp;Palmisano had invested approximately $8 million of his compensation in
the account. Mr.&nbsp;Palmisano could have chosen not to defer, taken these
funds from IBM and put them in other investment vehicles. Had he done so, these
numbers would not be disclosed here.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.15in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
table below shows the deferral elections and accumulated balances that are owed
to the Chairman and CEO from his prior years&#146; earned compensation. Like all
participants, Mr.&nbsp;Palmisano&#146;s savings are subject to investment returns.
As a result, the value of these account balances will change over time
depending on market performance. When Mr.&nbsp;Palmisano retires, the value of
his deferrals under the Excess 401(k)&nbsp;Plus Plan will be paid to him in
five equal installments over five years.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.15in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Ten-Year History of Chairman and CEO Palmisano&#146;s Deferred
Compensation (Nonqualified)</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

  </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:2.5%;">
  <p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="11%" colspan="2" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:11.0%;">
  <p align="right" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">4,782,542</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="background:#CCEEFF;padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:1.0%;">
  <p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>

 <tr height="0">
  <td width="438" style="border:none;"></td>
  <td width="19" style="border:none;"></td>
  <td width="8" style="border:none;"></td>
  <td width="74" style="border:none;"></td>
  <td width="19" style="border:none;"></td>
  <td width="8" style="border:none;"></td>
  <td width="74" style="border:none;"></td>
  <td width="19" style="border:none;"></td>
  <td width="8" style="border:none;"></td>

  <td width="7" style="border:none;"></td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">HOW
COMPENSATION DECISIONS ARE MADE</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">At
any level, compensation reflects an employee&#146;s value to the business &#151; market
value of skills, individual contribution and business results. To be sure we
appropriately assess the value of senior leaders, IBM follows an evaluation
process, described here in some detail:</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.05in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">1. Making
Commitments</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.05in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">At
the beginning of each year, all IBM employees, including Chairman and CEO Palmisano
and the other senior leaders, make a Personal Business Commitment (PBC) of the
goals, both qualitative and quantitative, they seek to achieve that year in
support of the business. These commitments are reviewed and approved by each
individual&#146;s manager. Chairman and CEO Palmisano&#146;s commitments are reviewed
directly by the Board of Directors.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">2. Determining Senior Vice Presidents (SVPs) Compensation</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.05in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Evaluation of Results by the Chairman and CEO</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Throughout
the year, employees assess their progress against their PBCs. At year end,
employees at all levels, including executives, work with their managers to
evaluate their own results &#151; not only with regard to their stated goals, but in
relation to how well their peers and the entire Company performed.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
self-assessments of the SVPs are reviewed by the Senior Vice President of Human
Resources (SVP HR) and Chairman and CEO Palmisano, who evaluate the
information, along with the following:</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.15in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:8.5pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Comparisons
to market compensation levels for cash compensation and total direct
compensation;</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:8.5pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Potential
for future roles within IBM; and</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:8.5pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Total
compensation levels relative to internal peers before and after any
recommendations.</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Following
this in-depth review and in consultation with the SVP HR, Mr.&nbsp;Palmisano
makes compensation recommendations to the Compensation Committee based on his
evaluation of each senior manager&#146;s performance and expectations for the coming
year.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Evaluation of Results by the Compensation Committee</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
Compensation Committee decides whether to approve or adjust the Chairman and
CEO&#146;s recommendations for the members of his team.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
Committee evaluates all of the factors considered by the Chairman and CEO and
reviews compensation summaries for each senior leader that tally the dollar
value of all compensation and related programs, including salary, annual
incentive, long-term compensation, deferred compensation, retention payments
and pension benefits.</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">21</font></p>

<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='21',FILE='C:\JMS\kdefran\09-1945-1\task3394969\1945-1-bc-05.htm',USER='kdefran',CD='Feb 27 16:48 2009' -->



<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">3. Determining Chairman and CEO
Compensation&#151;Research, Recommendations and Review</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.05in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">IBM&#146;s
SVP HR works directly with the chair of the Compensation Committee to provide a
decision-making framework for use in making a recommendation for the Chairman
and CEO&#146;s total compensation. This framework includes the Chairman and CEO&#146;s
evaluation of how well he believes he performed against his commitments in the
year, with an assessment of his performance against the Company&#146;s stated
strategic objectives. In addition to the above, the Committee also reviews an
analysis of IBM&#146;s total performance over the past year and a competitive
benchmark analysis furnished by the Committee&#146;s outside consultant (Towers Perrin).</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
Compensation Committee separately reviews all relevant information and arrives
at its recommendation for the Chairman and CEO&#146;s total compensation. In this
work, they are assisted by the Compensation Committee&#146;s outside consultant.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.15in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
final pay recommendation for the Chairman and CEO is presented to the independent
directors on IBM&#146;s Board for further review, discussion and final approval.
This process is followed every year.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.15in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">4. Ensuring Competitive Pay&#151;Approach to Benchmarking</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">IBM
participates in several executive compensation bench-marking surveys that
provide detail on levels of salary, target annual incentives and long-term
incentives, the relative mix of short- and long-term incentives, and mix of
cash and stock-based pay. We include in these surveys a broad range of key
information technology companies, given the battle for talent that exists in
our industry and to help us identify trends in the industry. We also include
companies outside our industry, with stature, size and complexity that
approximate our own, in recognition of the fact that competition for senior
management talent is not limited to our industry. These surveys are
supplemented by input from the Compensation Committee&#146;s outside consultant on
factors such as recent</font>  </font>market
trends. The companies used in the benchmarking surveys for 2008 compensation
decisions are listed below. The Committee reviews and approves this list
annually. For 2009, the Committee has approved the same list of companies with
the exception of AIG.</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" style="border-collapse:collapse;width:100.0%;">

</table>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
data from these surveys and related sources form the primary external view of
the market, and the Company&#146;s philosophy is to generally target the median of
the market for cash and total compensation for IBM job roles compared to jobs
of similar size and complexity at companies within our benchmarking group. For
individual compensation decisions, the information is used together with an
internal view of longer-term potential and individual performance relative to
other executives. For the Company&#146;s senior level executives, the Compensation
Committee also takes into account long-term retention objectives, recognizing
that their skills and experience are highly sought after by other companies
and, in particular, by the Company&#146;s competitors.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">5. Compensation Committee Consultant</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.05in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
Committee currently retains a Managing Director of Towers Perrin as its outside
compensation consultant to advise the Committee on market practices and the
specific IBM policies and programs. This Managing Director does not perform any
other consulting work for the Company, reports directly to the Compensation
Committee Chairman, and takes direction from the Committee. The consultant&#146;s
work for the Committee includes data analyses, market assessments, and
preparation of related</font>  </font>reports.
The work done by Towers Perrin for the Committee is documented in a formal
scope of work and contract which is executed by the consultant and the
Committee.</p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">22</font></p>

<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

</div>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='22',FILE='C:\JMS\wlabarr\09-1945-1\task3394984\1945-1-bc-07.htm',USER='wlabarr',CD='Feb 27 16:53 2009' -->


<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<div style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.15in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Towers
Perrin is one of the few human resource consulting companies with global
capabilities, and the Company&#146;s engagements with Towers Perrin primarily
involve advice outside the U.S. in a select number of countries where their
capabilities lead others in these marketplaces with respect to local benefit
issues such as pension design.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.15in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
Committee enters into a consulting agreement with its outside compensation
consultant on an annual basis. In determining whether or not to renew the
engagement with Towers Perrin, the Committee evaluates the quality of the
consulting service and annually assesses the nature and significance of the
Company&#146;s other engagements with Towers Perrin and the projected scope of work
for the coming year. Based on the assessment for 2008, the Committee determined
that the consultant is free of any relationships that would impair professional
judgment and advice to the Compensation Committee.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.15in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">CHAIRMAN
AND CEO COMPENSATION DECISIONS FOR 2008 AND 2009</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
Compensation Committee made decisions for the Chairman and CEO&#146;s 2008 and 2009
compensation following the process described above and using the pay components
shown above. The Compensation Committee noted the following as key points
regarding the Chairman and CEO&#146;s performance against his Personal Business
Commitments for 2008:</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:8.5pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Achieved
very strong financial performance including record revenue, profit, cash flow
and earnings per share (EPS) in a challenging economic environment</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:8.5pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Continued
to drive IBM to be the leading globally integrated enterprise</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:8.5pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Established
a growth markets organization to capture the business opportunity in these fast
growing economies</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:8.5pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Invested
in workforce and leadership programs for employees worldwide to motivate high
performance and drive business objectives</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:8.5pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Returned
significant value to shareholders including increasing dividends from $2.1
billion in 2007 to $2.6 billion in 2008</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:8.5pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Increased
IBM&#146;s leading market position in middleware and maintained leading market
position in services and servers</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:8.5pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Generated
highest services pre-tax profit dollars and margin in the last 5 years, driven
in part by global delivery, quality and efficiency</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:8.5pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Expanded
IBM&#146;s capabilities and financial performance through executing the acquisition
strategy, including the integration of business intelligence leader Cognos</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:8.5pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Continued
leadership in technology and innovation, earning more U.S. patents than any
other company for the 16th consecutive year</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
Committee considered these results and recommended that Mr.&nbsp;Palmisano
receive $5,500,000 in annual incentive for his 2008 performance.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
Committee worked with its outside consultant (Towers Perrin) to review Mr.&nbsp;Palmisano&#146;s
base salary, annual incentive target and long-term incentive award value using
a framework of competitive benchmark analysis, Company performance and Mr.&nbsp;Palmisano&#146;s
personal performance. Based on this review, the Committee recommended that Mr.&nbsp;Palmisano&#146;s
base salary and target annual incentive for 2009 remain at $1,800,000 and
$5,000,000, respectively.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.15in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
Committee recommended a 2009 long-term incentive award comprised entirely of
2009-2011 Performance Share Units valued at $12,000,000. The 2008 award was
valued at $11,000,000. The 2009 grant will be made on June&nbsp;8, 2009. The
Committee chose the long-term incentive value to improve Mr.&nbsp;Palmisano&#146;s
position relative to competitive benchmarks and to signal the Committee&#146;s
desire for him to continue his focus on taking the steps necessary to position
the Company for long-term success.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.15in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
Committee&#146;s recommendations were approved by the independent directors on IBM&#146;s
Board.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.15in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">SVP
COMPENSATION DECISIONS FOR 2008 AND 2009</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
Compensation Committee also made decisions for each of the executive officers
following the process described above and using a mix of the components shown
above. The Compensation Committee noted the following as key points for each of
the other named executive officers:</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Mark Loughridge, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:8.5pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Managed
IBM&#146;s long-term financial model to perform ahead of plan</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:8.5pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Exceeded
net income and EPS objectives</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:8.5pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Exceeded
cash flow objectives in a difficult global economic environment</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .25in;text-indent:-.25in;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:8.5pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Managed
IBM&#146;s portfolio, including execution of 15 acquisitions</p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">23</font></p>

<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="left"></div>

</div>
